sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Brunei Darussalam is a small, wealthy nation on the island of Borneo in Southeast Asia, known for its oil and gas reserves, Islamic traditions, and high standard of living.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Bandar Seri Begawan is the capital and largest city of Brunei, home to the Sultan’s palace and the iconic Omar Ali Saifuddien Mosque.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency is the Brunei dollar (BND), which is pegged to the Singapore dollar.

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Malay, though English is widely used in business and education.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Popular dishes include nasi katok (rice with fried chicken and sambal), ambuyat (sago starch dish), satay, and beef rendang.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Brunei is located on the northern coast of Borneo, bordered by Malaysia and the South China Sea. It features tropical rainforests, rivers, and coastal areas.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Brunei’s culture is deeply influenced by Malay traditions and Islam. The monarchy and Islamic values play a central role in daily life.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourism highlights include the Omar Ali Saifuddien Mosque, Kampong Ayer (the water village), Ulu Temburong National Park, and the Royal Regalia Museum.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: Brunei has one of the world’s highest car ownership rates, with more cars than people in some households.

history.event: Brunei was part of the Srivijaya and Majapahit empires, serving as a regional trading hub.
The Sultanate of Brunei rose to power, controlling much of Borneo and parts of the Philippines.
Brunei reached its peak under Sultan Bolkiah, becoming a dominant maritime power in Southeast Asia.
Brunei’s influence declined due to internal strife and European colonial expansion in the region.
Brunei became a British protectorate, retaining its monarchy but losing much of its territory.
Oil was discovered in Brunei, transforming its economy and ensuring wealth for the nation.
A new constitution was introduced, affirming Brunei’s internal self-government under the Sultan.
Brunei gained full independence from Britain and joined the United Nations.
Brunei has maintained political stability under Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah, with wealth from oil and gas supporting its welfare state.
